narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: skills with supercollider, thorough overview of sound synthesis techniques
A lot of fundamental knowledge of how we perceive sound and what techniques can be used to recreate realistic sounds. Learned a lot about SuperCollider.
I was able to refine my coding skills of  a program that will be useful for my work, and get a better understanding of digital sound
how to create instruments virtually with code and make ambient sound with it
I learned about how sound is represented digitally and how to synthesize it using SuperCollider.
Sound synthesis, composition. Came into the class with no musical knowledge, now I know quite a bit. It was great!
Computer music history, acoustics, SuperCollider-specific programming
introduction to the supercollider programming language, the basics of digital audio and various techniques for sound synthesis

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Scott is a great professor. He is very passionate about the subject and is extremely open to feedback about his delivery of material, material covered in class, and general questions.

Strengths - you get pretty low level and really learn about sound synthesis and how different sounds are created
Weaknesses - there's so much ground we try and cover that lectures often are too fast paced, requiring me to rewatch them at a later time. If this were an in person, non-recorded lecture, I'd struggle to keep up in class.
it was a well informed class, I didn't find any weaknesses in delivering the material
The lectures were easy to get but only if you did the readings. The assignments were pretty helpful and gave many hints.
The assignment specs are somewhat confusing and it's hard to get started with SuperCollider.
Strengths: Interesting content and assignments

Strengths: Scott is an excellent teacher. Super funny and charming, very engaging, a blast to be around.

Weaknesses: some more organization to the slides wouldn't hurt.

Great introduction to the subject, very generous psets that allow you to explore without feeling constrained. Great instructors and flexible timeline. More focus on arrangement techniques might be nice

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Live coding actually worked really well with a virtual context. Instead of having to strain to look at a projection, it was easy to see code or follow along on my own computer. However, for some more theoretical discussions, it would have been helpful to incorporate more of a digital blackboard/screenshared iPad (happened in the 2nd half of class, wish this was used more).
Learning audio through zoom is always an intricate nightmare.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, especially if you are interested in experimenting with composing music with electronic sounds.

I... would recommend it if you're interested in computer music. I hesitate because the semester started off kind of rough, and Scott's snarky, prickly personality really rubbed me the wrong way. But to his immense credit, he really turned things around after he received critical mid-semester feedback. I truly respect and admire his willingness to adapt his teaching style after receiving not the nicest of comments, without being defensive or too prideful. 

In terms of the course, please recognize this is sound *synthesis*. It's all about starting from the most grating and jarring of sounds and seeing what it takes to make stuff that actually sounds kind of nice. This is not music composition using electronic samples, you have to build almost every sound you use from scratch. If you're interested in electronic music composition, 431 seems to be geared more towards that (though I haven't taken it, so idk). This is sound *synthesis*, just know what you're getting yourself into! Things will sound... bad for most of the semester. It definitely makes it quite rewarding in the end when things start to sound good, though.
Students who wish to get a better understanding of digital sound synthesis would benefit greatly from this course
Fun class for people interested in sound generation. Really good for coming up with a portfolio.
Id recommend this course to a student with some kind of music project in mind beforehand
Sure! It's fun but the language used (SuperCollider) is a bit of a pain to use.
Yes, def take it with Prof Scott!!!
YES TAKE IT IF YOU LIKE MUSIC AND PROGRAMMING
